title: Encouragement to Rebuild
shortSummary: Haggai 2 records God's encouragement to Zerubbabel, Joshua, and the people to be strong and continue rebuilding the temple despite its humble beginnings. The chapter highlights God's promise to fill the new temple with greater glory than the former and assures His presence and blessing amid trials and challenges.
timeline: c. 520 BC - Post-exilic period during the reign of Darius I

keyCharacters.name: Zerubbabel
keyCharacters.description: Governor of Judah and descendant of King David, chosen by God to lead the rebuilding of the temple.

keyCharacters.name: Joshua (Jeshua) the son of Josedech
keyCharacters.description: High priest who served alongside Zerubbabel in leading the restoration of temple worship.

keyCharacters.name: Haggai
keyCharacters.description: Prophet who delivers God's messages encouraging the people to rebuild the temple and trust in His promises.

definitions.definition: A seal or ring used to authenticate documents, symbolizing authority and divine approval.
The rebuilt temple after the exile, contrasted with the former temple built by Solomon.
Refers to the solemn agreement God made with Israel, especially the promises given at the Exodus.
Meat from sacrificial offerings that was considered consecrated and set apart for God.

outline.heading: Encouragement to Rebuild the Temple
outline.description: God encourages Zerubbabel, Joshua, and the people to be strong and not discouraged by the temple's current appearance, promising that the glory of the new temple will surpass the former and that His Spirit remains with them.

outline.heading: Instruction on Ritual Purity
outline.description: God instructs the priests regarding the holiness of objects touched by holy or unclean things, illustrating how the people's unfaithfulness has made their work and offerings unclean.

outline.heading: Call to Consider God's Blessing
outline.description: The prophet calls the people to reflect on their hardships since the temple's foundation was laid and assures them that from this day forward God will bless their efforts.

outline.heading: Godâ€™s Sovereign Power and Promise to Zerubbabel
outline.description: God declares His power to shake the nations and overthrow kingdoms, and He promises to make Zerubbabel a signet of His authority, affirming his chosen role in God's plan.

application: Trust in God's presence and promises even when your work seems small or discouraging.
Be strong and obedient in the tasks God has given you, knowing He is with you.
Reflect on past difficulties as opportunities to recognize God's blessing when He turns circumstances around.
Recognize that God sovereignly appoints leaders and uses them for His purposes; pray for those in spiritual and civil authority.

keyVerses.text: Yet now be strong, O Zerubbabel, saith the LORD; and be strong, O Joshua, son of Josedech, the high priest; and be strong, all ye people of the land, saith the LORD, and work: for I am with you, saith the LORD of hosts:
keyVerses.significance: This verse emphasizes God's presence as the source of strength and encouragement for His people to continue their work.

keyVerses.text: The glory of this latter house shall be greater than of the former, saith the LORD of hosts: and in this place will I give peace, saith the LORD of hosts.
keyVerses.significance: God promises a greater glory and peace in the rebuilt temple, encouraging hope beyond present circumstances.

keyVerses.text: In that day, saith the LORD of hosts, will I take thee, O Zerubbabel, my servant, the son of Shealtiel, saith the LORD, and will make thee as a signet: for I have chosen thee, saith the LORD of hosts.
keyVerses.significance: This verse affirms God's sovereign choice of Zerubbabel as a symbol of His authority and faithfulness to His covenant.
